sequence.text: As you’re taking a round in the warehouse in the morning, Dev approaches you with a complaint against his team mate, Kumar
Kumar and I are scheduled for the same warehouse shift.
He regularly plays games on his cell phone while I pick the orders.
I have to do the bulk of the work while he plays.
I've asked him on four different occasions to help me, but he doesn't listen to me.

content.description: You’ve already reprimanded Kumar in the past about his slack behaviour. What kind of disciplinary action should you take against him now?
options: Send Kumar a notification of termination
Scold Kumar in front of his team mates
Set strict productivity targets for Kumar

reactions.confirmText: Are you sure you want to terminate Kumar without giving him a chance to take responsibility?
reactions.noText: I’m a softie; I can’t fire anyone really
reactions.text:
You’ve fired Kumar without allowing him a chance to take responsibility. This has negatively affected the morale of the employees. 
Workers feel that your response was disproportionate to Kumar’s offence and now feel discouraged and worried about their own job security.

reactions.confirmText: Are you sure you want to embarrass Kumar like that?
reactions.yesText: I want to discourage others from this kind of behaviour
reactions.noText: perhaps that won’t let me cultivate a trusting relationship
reactions.text:
You gave Kumar a dressing down in front of others. He resents you now as he has become a laughing stock for a group of warehouse workers. 
He wants to quit and his friends are not happy about how things panned out either.

reactions.confirmText: Are you sure you want to give Kumar a second chance?
reactions.yesText: it’s the only way I’ll be able to build trust in the team
reactions.noText: he lacks discipline and won’t change his behaviour
reactions.text: You did the right thing by giving Kumar a chance to take responsibility and become more professional. You made him and—by extension—others in the team feel supported and laid the ground for cultivating a more trusting relationship with the employees.

sequence.text: You’re having a meal in the break room when you hear some gossip about Maya shouting at Jay the day before. You see Jay and Maya separately and ask them what had happened.

I clean out the shared refrigerator regularly and accidentally threw out Maya’s leftovers yesterday. She absolutely went off at me for that! No one appreciates the effort I put in to keep this place clean.
I had left some food in the fridge and found it missing! What gave Jay the right to discard it? People should respect others’ personal belongings..

content.description: Jay and Maya are not speaking to each other. How should you handle this situation?
options: Avoid confrontation as long as it doesn’t affect their productivity
Talk to Maya and tell her not to take Jay’s action personally
Facilitate a discussion between the two to arrive at a resolution

reactions.confirmText: Are you sure you want to avoid any confrontations?
reactions.text:
It’s not good to let conflicts fester in the workplace. 
It may not affect their productivity, but it might affect the general environment at work and there’s a real chance that one or both individuals may engage in passive-aggressive behaviour.

reactions.confirmText: Are you sure you want to talk to only Maya?
reactions.yesText: it was an accident and Maya shouldn’t have shouted at Jay
reactions.noText: I should lead both Maya and Jay into an open discussion
reactions.text:
Research has shown that telling people not to take conflicts personally doesn’t work. 
Regardless of such a disclaimer, Maya is very likely to hold a grudge against Jay that will ultimately affect their working relationship.

reactions.confirmText: Are you sure you want to spend time on discussing such a minor issue?
reactions.yesText: if they don’t talk it out, they will act it out
reactions.noText: why stir the pot further unnecessarily?
reactions.text:
The sooner you address an issue and allow employees to engage in a dialogue, the sooner they can go back to a healthy working relationship and remain productive and engaged. 
Ask both parties to share their perspectives and invite them to come up with ideas for a resolution that may include apologies or changes in behaviour (labelling food containers, in this case, for instance) to prevent similar disputes from recurring.

sequence.text: Two team leaders visit you in your office with a scheduling conflict for which they can’t work out an amiable solution.

Both our teams are scheduled to carry out an inventory accuracy check right now for two different customers. As you know, we only have one electric stacker in the warehouse, and both our teams need it to bring down products from heavy duty racks
We can’t reach a compromise; which team should get the electric stacker?

content.description: How should you manage this intergroup conflict?
options: Analyse load and priority of customers and allocate stacker accordingly
Motivate the team leaders to collaborate on finding the best solution
Tell management you need to buy another stacker for the warehouse

reactions.confirmText: Are you sure you want to make this decision on behalf of both parties?
reactions.yesText: it would be the easiest way to resolve this conflict
reactions.noText: I want to inculcate decision-making skills in my staff
reactions.text:
You analysed the load and priority of both customer operations and made the decision to allocate the stacker towards checking the inventory of the customer that brings in greater revenue. 
 The team leader in charge of the other account is not happy about your decision and, in the absence of an open discussion, thinks that you showed favouritism.
Moreover, it does not give people the confidence that they are capable of handling issues on their own.

reactions.confirmText: Are you sure you want to spend time on motivating the team leaders to arrive at a solution together? It would easier to make a decision yourself.
reactions.yesText: the team leaders should be able to collaborate on a solution
reactions.noText: that’s right, it would be easier to make a decision on my own
reactions.text:
Allowing members to work together in finding a resolution is a great approach. An open discussion that looks at the perspectives of both parties and identifies the conflict’s impacts on their separate operations leads to a greater understanding between colleagues.
This not only improves employee relationships but increases collaboration and efficiency as people learn to arrive at solutions together without always pushing the issues up the organisational chain.

reactions.confirmText: Are you sure you want to purchase an additional stacker?
reactions.yesText: it would prevent this kind of problem from occurring ever again
reactions.noText: it would mean a huge expense for an infrequent scheduling issue
reactions.text: The management tells you that they can purchase another stacker at the start of next quarter, ifthe budget allows it.

sequence.text: You notice that the outbound team is struggling to meet their targets for the day while the inbound team is relaxing and having a chat. You talk to a floor supervisor about it.
The inbound team regularly completes their targets for the day by 4 p.m. but do not move on to help the outbound team.
They say that they are paid wages and will only do the workload assigned to them in the morning.

content.description: How should you manage this contentious situation?
options: Move a few people from the inbound to the outbound team
Encourage teams to collaborate to meet business objectives
Recruit extra workers for the outbound team

reactions.confirmText: Are you sure you want to permanently move some people from the inbound to the outbound team?
reactions.yesText: this will solve the issue once and for all
reactions.noText: I need to look for a more lasting solution
reactions.text: While moving a few people from one team to another will solve the issue for the time being, the situation is not likely to always remain the same. It’s more important to align each team’s goals       with the overall goals of the organisation so that whatever the conditions, the teams feel motivated to work out a way to achieve the organisational goals together.

reactions.confirmText: Are you sure you want to spend time motivating teams to collaborate instead of reorganising teams to achieve the productivity targets for the day?
reactions.yesText: this will ensure that teams work towards common goals
reactions.noText: I need to meet the day’s targets by hook or by crook
reactions.text:
Devoting time to encourage teams to collaborate and reminding everyone what the common objectives are helps to create accountability.
Focus on finding long-term solutions through such actions as motivating teams to achieve group goals instead of always chasing short-term goals.

reactions.confirmText: Are you sure you want to spend time and resources on recruiting more workers?
reactions.noText: it will cost too much to train new people
reactions.text: Adding more resources to a team would sure help to increase productivity but it will also add to the labour costs. As a manager, you have to be mindful of the costs while working towards increased throughput.
